dt.t: a {wi}harried{/wi} waiter who forgets your order

dt: {bc}to make a pillaging or destructive raid on {bc}{sx|assault||}
{bc}to force to move along by harassing

dt.t: {wi}harrying{/wi} the terrified horses down out of the mountains

dt: {bc}to torment by or as if by constant attack

pt: {sc}worry{/sc} {sc}annoy{/sc} {sc}harass{/sc} {sc}harry{/sc} {sc}plague{/sc} {sc}pester{/sc} {sc}tease{/sc} mean to disturb or irritate by persistent acts. {sc}worry{/sc} implies an incessant goading or attacking that drives one to desperation.

pt.t: pursued a policy of {it}worrying{/it} the enemy

pt: {sc}annoy{/sc} implies disturbing one's composure or peace of mind by intrusion, interference, or petty attacks.

pt.t: you're doing that just to {it}annoy{/it} me

pt: {sc}harass{/sc} implies petty persecutions or burdensome demands that exhaust one's nervous or mental power.
{sc}harry{/sc} may imply heavy oppression or maltreatment.

pt.t: the strikers had been {it}harried{/it} by thugs

pt: {sc}plague{/sc} implies a painful and persistent affliction.
{sc}pester{/sc} stresses the repetition of petty attacks.
{sc}tease{/sc} suggests an attempt to break down one's resistance or rouse to wrath.

et: Middle English {it}hærȝen, herien, harien, herwen, harwen{/it} "to plunder, ravage, torment, pursue, drag," going back to Old English {it}hergian, herian, heregian, hergon{/it} "to make predatory raids, ravage, wage war," going back to Germanic {it}*harjōjan-{/it} (whence also Old Saxon {it}herion{/it} "to plunder," Middle Dutch {it}heren, hergen{/it} "to destroy with an army, ravage," Old High German {it}heriōn, herrōn{/it} "to devastate, plunder," Old Norse {it}herja{/it} "to despoil, lay waste"), verbal derivative of {it}*harja-{/it} "body of armed men" (whence Old English {it}here{/it} "body of armed men, army," Old Frisian {it}here{/it} [in compounds], Old Saxon {it}heri{/it} "army, crowd," Old High German {it}heri, hari,{/it} Old Norse {it}herr{/it} "host, army," Gothic {it}harjis{/it}), going back to Indo-European {it}*kori̯o-{/it} (whence also Middle Irish {it}cuire{/it} "troop, host, company," Middle Welsh {it}cord, cordd{/it} "tribe, clan, multitude, troop," Lithuanian {it}kãrias{/it} "war, army"), derivative of appurtenance from {it}*kor-{/it} "war," whence Lithuanian {it}kãras{/it} "war," Old Persian {it}kāra-{/it} "army, people" (with lengthened grade?); also, with suffix {it}-no-,{/it} Greek {it}koíranos{/it} "commander, ruler" (< {it}*koironos{/it} < {it}*kori̯o-no-s{/it})

Old English forms such as {it}her{/it}({it}e{/it}){it}gian,{/it} 3rd singular present {it}hergaþ,{/it} show variants with reversion of palatal {it}g{/it} (= [j]) to velar {it}g{/it} (= [ɣ]) before a back vowel, though in this case there was no original {it}g,{/it} and the reversion is analogical. The two competing sets of forms were passed on to Middle English. The variants with either {it}-i-{/it} or {it}-w-{/it} gave rise to two more or less distinct words in modern English, {it}harry{/it} and {et_link|harrow:1|harrow:1}. For other words containing Old English {it}here{/it} "body of armed men" or Germanic {it}*harja-{/it} see {et_link|arrière-ban|arriere-ban}, {et_link|harbinger:1|harbinger:1}, {et_link|harbor:1|harbor:1}, {et_link|harness:1|harness:1}, {et_link|herald:1|herald:1}, {et_link|heriot|heriot}.
shortdef: to make a pillaging or destructive raid on : assault
to force to move along by harassing
to torment by or as if by constant attack
